main_definition: To be in someone's possession or control temporarily, especially as a result of an agreement or obligation.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Kept in the hand or arms; grasped firmly.
meanings_and_examples.example: He held the heavy box with both hands to prevent it from slipping.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To have (a record, award, etc.) as a personal possession; claim or own.
meanings_and_examples.example: She was proud that she had won the first prize in the art competition and held her certificate high for everyone to see.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Held responsible or accountable for something.
meanings_and_examples.example: He was held liable for damages after his company's product caused harm.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To have someone arrested and in police custody.
meanings_and_examples.example: The suspect was held by the local authorities until they could verify their identity.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To support or assist with something; provide a base for.
meanings_and_examples.example: During the presentation, she relied on her colleagues to hold up various slides and visuals.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To be in charge of keeping track of (someone) over an extended period of time, especially when they are not at home.
meanings_and_examples.example: The babysitter was held overnight due to the parents' unexpected change of plans.
